context_meta.author: third_watch
context_meta.title: Why This NBA Season Is More Important for the Lakers Than You Think
context_meta.summary: The 2017-18 NBA season doesn’t really exist for the Los Angeles Lakers. At least, not in the way it exists, for example, for the Golden State Warriors or the Cleveland Cavaliers or the Boston Celtics or the San Antonio Spurs, or even the Brooklyn Nets whose overperformance this year could scupper Cleveland’s best-laid plans. For Luke Walton, Magic Johnson and the rebuilding Lakers, the 2017-18 NBA season that begins on Thursday night at Quicken Loans Arena when the Celtics visit the Cavaliers is about intangibles, a deliberately frustrating and ambiguous term that stands, in this case, for small steps in the direction marked "Playoffs" and, eventually, the NBA Finals.

text: Lebron James is the Cavs. They have never been able to win games when he is not playing in them. He is the guy it all revolves around for better or worse. text: Warriors Vs Cavs, Cavs win in 6. For me, it all comes down to this, these are the averages of Cavs starters and Warriors starters in the just concluded finals, Lebron 35.5, Kyrie 32.2, Love, 14, JR 14 and TT 5.6 VS Durant 35.2, Steph 26.8, Klay 16.4, Green 10.2 and Zaza 3.2. In other words Cavs starters averaged 100 and the Warriors 92. I understand all the other nuances but one cannot hide from the fact that Cavs bench were ridiculously weak and they are the best now. I have my doubts IT even in perfect health can replicate Kyrie's success but with Love moving to the 5, if IT averages 20 and Love 15, that's more than Steph and Zaza combined and Cavs bench is off the charts. You are going to get way more contributions instead of the over reliance of a few players.

context_meta.title: The Thunder gave Kevin Durant’s jersey number to an undrafted rookie
context_meta.summary: There was a time Thunder fans dreamed of Kevin Durant’s jersey hanging from the rafters after several championships and years of memories, instead this happened. PJ Dozier is wearing No. 35 for the Thunder. It’s not like the Thunder should venerate Durant’s number or anything, he’s gone — but giving it to Dozier, a player on a two-way contract is a not-so-subtle jab.

context_meta.author: captainunderoos
context_meta.title: 7 NBA players who are destined for breakouts
context_meta.summary: Sure, we're all excited about watching LeBron James, Kevin Durant, Russell Westbrook and the rest of the big names finally play some regular season hoops in the NBA beginning Tuesday night. But who will you be thrilled to have watched by the end of the 2017-18 season? That's where this list comes in. Here are a handful of lesser-known names who will take that next step forward. 1. SF Taurean Prince, Atlanta Hawks Dale Zanine-USA TODAY Sports File this under "rebuilding teams who need someone to step up." Prince, the 12th overall pick out of Baylor in last year's draft dealt by the Utah Jazz as part of the Jeff Teague deal, had an eye-opening postseason in the series against the Wizards last season.

context_meta.author: ipostwhaticareabout
context_meta.title: Shaq: Knicks players failed Phil Jackson
context_meta.summary: Shaquille O'Neal says Phil Jackson meant well, but his cardinal sin during his three-year, three-month stint as Knicks president was trusting that millennial NBA players would adapt to the selfless aspects of the triangle. In a conference call promoting TNT's coverage, O'Neal supported Jackson's attempt at resurrecting the Knicks while Charles Barkley said he got “a bad rap'' and partner Kenny Smith believes he erred by not taking over the bench. The post-Jackson era begins Thursday in Oklahoma City with a new, high-tempo offense and new management team willing to de-emphasize making the playoffs for this one season in order to gain another high lottery pick.

On Monday, while defending his slow response to the deaths of four U.S. soldiers in Niger, Trump said: “If you look at President Obama, and other presidents, most of them didn’t make calls.

text: Poppo's brain continues to malfunction, what a jerk.

text: "Tack on the opportunity to join a team growing into a championship contender—as well as the chance to knock off the Warriors on the way—and the Lakers may become an irresistible choice next summer."  Oh that is the funniest thing I have read all week.

context_meta.author: third_watch
context_meta.title: Why This NBA Season Is More Important for the Lakers Than You Think
context_meta.summary: The 2017-18 NBA season doesn’t really exist for the Los Angeles Lakers. At least, not in the way it exists, for example, for the Golden State Warriors or the Cleveland Cavaliers or the Boston Celtics or the San Antonio Spurs, or even the Brooklyn Nets whose overperformance this year could scupper Cleveland’s best-laid plans. For Luke Walton, Magic Johnson and the rebuilding Lakers, the 2017-18 NBA season that begins on Thursday night at Quicken Loans Arena when the Celtics visit the Cavaliers is about intangibles, a deliberately frustrating and ambiguous term that stands, in this case, for small steps in the direction marked "Playoffs" and, eventually, the NBA Finals.

text: Even though he's a great player, LeBron should be let go.  He's a distraction as indicated by Kyrie wanting to leave.  He's also an outright liar accusing Dan Gilbert of writing a racist letter when he left for Miami.  In actuality he and his miserable posse are the real racists.  If it wasn't for his God given ability they would all either be pushing drugs or burgers.

context_meta.author: nanook
context_meta.title: Ex-Lakers PG Marcelo Huertas Says NBA Players Are 'Babies'
context_meta.summary: Marcelo Huertas had a rough run with the L.A. Lakers ... and now he's clapping back at his former team and the NBA for how they coddle their superstars. "In the NBA, players are babies ... everyone is afraid of dealing with the athletes," Huertas told Brazilian hoops blog Bala na Cesta.  "That's not a thing in Europe. If you step over the line, you're punished athletically, financially, you're thrown out, suspended, whatever the hell. That doesn't exist in the NBA. I would see things and say, 'There's no way this is possible."' Marcelo -- a Euroleague veteran -- says his 2 seasons with the Lakers were pretty tough on him emotionally ... claiming he put in a TON of hard work, even mentoring his

context_meta.author: DeltaBravo
context_meta.title: Inside how the Rockets landed Chris Paul
context_meta.summary: ON THE NIGHT of June 27, Chris Paul was hanging at 1 Oak in West Hollywood with LeBron James. The club thumped as Paul and LeBron exchanged greetings with Tristan Thompson and Joe Johnson, who dined with his wife at a nearby booth. When the clock struck 1 a.m. and they began plotting their exit from the private entrance ahead of the paparazzi, Paul noticed a text from his agent, Leon Rose. The trade to Houston had been consummated. Through a series of complex transactions -- including the acquisitions of Darrun Hilliard from Detroit and DeAndre Liggins from Dallas, then flipping them to the Clippers as part of a package for Paul -- the Rockets had swapped Patrick Beverley, Lou Williams, Sam Dekker,

context_meta.author: rocky.j.mountain
context_meta.title: Hawks will discipline Dennis Schroder for 'unacceptable' behavior following fight
context_meta.summary: The Hawks announced Monday point guard Dennis Schroder will be disciplined for his "unacceptable" behavior that led to his arrest on Sept. 29.  Hawks general manager Travis Schlenk said in a statement that the investigation into an alleged fight Schroder was involved in outside of a late-night restaurant is not complete, but the Hawks will "support Dennis as we would any of our players working through a situation." Schlenk also acknowledged Schroder's behavior was "unacceptable" and something that will not be tolerated by their franchise. The Hawks will discipline their point guard, but Schlenk did not disclose a plan as they are waiting for the investigation to develop further. "From our preliminary

context_meta.author: ipostwhaticareabout
context_meta.title: Could Rodney McGruder's injury help Heat?
context_meta.summary: When Rodney McGruder suffered a stress fracture last week, some Miami Heat fans were worried. McGruder routinely defended opposing teams' best perimeter players. The 25-year-old who had bounced around summer league teams and overseas squads before finding a home in Miami finished just shy of the NBA's All-Rookie team last year. But could McGruder's injury actually be a blessing in disguise for Miami? According to ESPN's real plus-minus formula, McGruder's injury led the Heat to jump from a projected 42.3 wins to 45 wins, and from seventh to fifth in the East. Josh Richardson is a better player according to the formula, and McGruder's injury means more minutes for Richardson. Of course, we'll

context_meta.author: ipostwhaticareabout
context_meta.title: Preston: Attendance is down at Ravens games. The reasons for no-shows are up
context_meta.summary: One problem seemed to worsen for the Ravens on Sunday. There were about 10,000 to 15,000 fan no-shows at M&T Bank Stadium for the Ravens' game against the Chicago Bears (announced attendance: a near-capacity 70,616). Critics of the Ravens' kneeling during the national anthem would like to take credit for the vacant seats, but that's just the latest of prevailing issues. Fan enthusiasm has been dipping for years, and it appeared to hit a low point last season when visitors from Philadelphia, Washington and Pittsburgh, adorned in their team's colors, occupied huge chunks of seats. The recent debate over whether NFL players should kneel or stand for the national anthem just gave fans another reason
